data.title: 21 bridges that tell the story of Dublin
data.meta_description: A look at all 21 bridges that span the Liffey in Dublin between Chapelizod and East Wall
data.text:
Anna Livia Bridge (1753, rebuilt mid-19th century)

Road bridge

Explain the name: Anna Livia Plurabelle is a character in James Joyce's Finnegans Wake, who personifies the Liffey.

Fact: It’s thought that there has been a bridge at this location in Chapelizod since at least the 14th century.

Island Bridge (1792)

Road bridge

Explain the name: There was once a man-made island here, after local monks cut a channel to divert water and create a mill race.

Fact: Was originally known as Sarah Bridge after Sarah Fane, Countess of Westmorland (1764-1793) until the formation of the Irish Free State in 1922, when it reverted to its original name.

Liffey Viaduct (1877)

Railway bridge

Explain the name: A utilitarian name for a utilitarian bridge.

Fact: Links Heuston Station with the north side of the city via a tunnel that runs for 692 metres under the Phoenix Park.

Seán Heuston Bridge (1828)

Luas bridge

Explain the name: Seán Heuston (1891-1916) was the youngest of those executed after the Easter Rising.

Fact: Phoenix Iron Works was awarded the prefix ‘Royal’ for its work on a bridge that now bears the name of a republican hero.

Frank Sherwin Bridge (1982)

Road bridge

Explain the name: Frank Sherwin (1905-1981) was a Dublin republican, and long-serving city councillor.

Fact: The bridge deck is made up of a single piece of reinforced concrete.

Rory O’More Bridge (1861)

Road bridge

Explain the name: Rory O’More (born c. 1600) was a leader of the Irish Rebellion of 1641.

Fact: There was a significant cost overrun by the time the bridge was completed – from the original estimate of 7,556 guineas to 11,000 guineas.

James Joyce Bridge (2003)

Road bridge

Explain the name: James Joyce (1882-1941) wrote arguably the great Irish novel, Ulysses.

Fact: The bridge was opened on the annual day of James Joyce celebration, Bloomsday, on June 16th 2003.

Mellows Bridge (1768)

Road bridge

Explain the name: Liam Mellows was an Easter Rising veteran and anti-Treaty republican who was executed by Free State forces in 1922.

Fact: The oldest surviving bridge in the city.

Father Mathew Bridge (1818)

Road bridge

Explain the name: Father Theobald Mathew (1790-1856) founded the Irish Total Abstinence Society and is said to be responsible for over six million people giving up alcohol worldwide.

Fact: There has been a river crossing at this location since at least the year 1000.

O’Donovan Rossa Bridge (1816)

Road bridge

Explain the name: Jeremiah O'Donovan Rossa (1831-1915) was a Fenian leader whose eulogy was given by Patrick Pearse.

Fact: Wider than any bridge in London when it was built.

Grattan Bridge (1875)

Road bridge

Explain the name: Politician Henry Grattan (1746-1820) was instrumental in achieving free trade and parliamentary independence for Ireland.

Fact: In the 18th century, a large statue of King George I on a horse stood on a pier beside the first bridge that was built on this spot. It’s now in an art gallery in Birmingham, England.

Millennium Bridge (1999)

Pedestrian bridge

Explain the name: Two possible names were discussed in council – Frank Cluskey Bridge, after the former Lord Mayor of Dublin, and Millennium Bridge.

Fact: The entire bridge deck was driven to Dublin from Carlow and lowered into place by a single crane.

Ha’penny Bridge (1816)

Pedestrian bridge

Explain the name: For around its first 100 years in existence, it cost a ha’penny to cross the bridge.

Fact: Used by an estimated 30,000 people every day.

O’Connell Bridge (1880)

Road bridge

Explain the name: Daniel O’Connell (1775-1847) was a political leader and reformist who helped secure Catholic emancipation in Ireland.

Fact: The bridge is wider than it is long.

Rosie Hackett Bridge (2014)

Road and Luas bridge

Explain the name: Rosie Hackett (1892-1976) was a trade union leader who also took part in the Easter Rising

Fact: The only bridge across the Liffey in Dublin to be named after a woman.

Butt Bridge (1932)

Road bridge

Explain the name: Isaac Butt (1813-1879) was a conservative-turned-nationalist politician, remembered as the Father of Home Rule.

Fact: The current bridge replaced a previous Butt Bridge which had stood for 51 years after 1879 – the year Isaac Butt died.

Loopline Bridge (1891)

Railway bridge

Explain the name: The bridge forms part of the looped section of railway track between Connolly and Pearse stations.

Fact: Highly controversial when it was built as it blocked views of the Custom House.

Talbot Memorial Bridge (1978)

Road bridge

Explain the name: Matt Talbot (1856-1925) was an alcoholic Dubliner who went on to become a symbol of sobriety and piety.

Fact: The first new bridge across the Liffey after the rebuilding of Butt Bridge in 1932, it was required to ease traffic congestion.

Seán O’Casey Bridge (2005)

Pedestrian bridge

Explain the name: Seán O'Casey (1880-1964) was a dramatist and champion of Dublin’s working classes.

Fact: A swing bridge, it’s been nicknamed ‘the quiver in the river’ due to the way it moves under your feet.

Samuel Beckett Bridge (2009)

Road bridge

Explain the name: Named after Dublin-born writer Samuel Beckett (1906-1989) who lived in Paris for most of his adult life and is buried there.

Fact: Was transported from Rotterdam in the Netherlands to Dublin by barge.

Tom Clarke Bridge (1984)
